etymologies: late 16th century (in the sense ‘interrupt’): from Latin interpellat- ‘interrupted (by speech)’, from the verb interpellare, from inter- ‘between’ + pellere ‘to drive’. interpellate (sense 1) dates from the late 19th century; interpellate (sense 2) is from the works of Althusser

definitions: (in certain parliamentary systems) interrupt the order of the day by demanding an explanation from (the minister concerned).
shortDefinitions: (in parliament) interrupt order of day by demanding explanation from

definitions: (of an ideology or discourse) bring into being or give identity to (an individual or category).
shortDefinitions: (of ideology or discourse) bring into being or give identity to
